awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Understanding Climate Processes with Causal Discovery and Graphs of Information Flow in the Coupled Atmosphere-Land-Ocean System
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to develop graphical models of causal discovery and apply them to topics the field of climate dynamics.  In these models lagged correlations are used to identify pathways of causal influence among components of a coupled system, and the model is constructed by representing each component as one node of a directed graph.  Edges between node are assigned values representing the extent to which one component is predictable given prior knowledge of another.  A key issue in causal discovery is accounting for indirect effects, in which component A influences component B which in turn influences component C, as opposed to the case in which component A directly influences component C.  In graphical terms the distinction is whether or not an edge exists between A and C, or whether A's connection to C is only through B. This evaluation is done through a statistical calculation of conditional probabilities.   Previous work by the PIs applied causal discovery to identify relationships among four well-known teleconnection patterns, the Western Pacific and Eastern Pacific Oscillations (WPO and EPO), the North Atlantic Oscillation (NAO), and the Pacific/North America (PNA) pattern.  In this case the method shows that the EPO can affect the NAO 18 days later, while the NAO can influence the PNA pattern three to six days later. Although the application to atmospheric science is novel, the method has been used successfully in other disciplines including economics, systems engineering, and bioinformatics.

Work under the project will further develop the modeling technique, with a goal of increasing computational speed by a factor of 100 through improvements in parallelization and localization of memory access.  Visualization tools will also be developed to display results.  In addition to these development efforts, the PIs will apply the technique to address three topics in climate dynamics: the onset dynamics of the Asian summer monsoon, the subseasonal variation of the Northern Hemisphere annual mode (NAM), and changes in the characteristics of information flow in global warming simulations.  Work on monsoon onset will focus on three questions: What are the critical processes responsible for the establishment of the cross-equatorial flow? How important is the mechanical and thermal forcing associated with the Tibetan Plateau for the onset compared to local air-sea interaction in the Bay of Bengal and South China Sea? Is the onset a direct manifestation of atmospheric instability?  For subseasonal NAM variability, the research goal is to investigate the relative importance of tropospheric dynamics, stratosphere-troposphere coupling, and troposphere-surface coupling in determining the phase transition of the NAM.  The work on global warming is based on a preliminary analysis of one simulation in which information flows in the Northern midlatitudes become weaker as the climate warms, suggesting a reduction in atmospheric predictability in the tropics and mid-latitudes.

The work has broader impacts through the introduction of a methodology developed in one scientific discipline (economics) into another (climate dynamics).  The PIs will promote the adoption of the modeling technique by making their algorithms and software available to the community of climate dynamics researchers through a web portal.  They will also offer tutorials at scientific conferences including the annual meetings of the American Meteorological Society and the American Geophysical Union.  Tutorial materials will also be made available online and through published papers.  In addition, the project will support and train a graduate students and a postdoctoral fellow, thereby providing for the future workforce in this research area.

por.por_cntn:
Causal discovery, defined as the process of identifying cause-and-effect hypotheses from observational data, has been applied with great success in many disciplines including economics, systems engineering and bioinformatics. The PIs of this project were the first to demonstrate to the climate community the great potential of causal discovery through probabilistic graphical models using two case studies that revealed sub-monthly-scale causal relations among extratropical teleconnection patterns and extracted major atmospheric information pathways in a causality-based climate network. With this NSF support, adopting the idea of interpreting active dynamical processes as information flow, the PIs have expanded the scope of causal discovery analysis for climate research through establishing a testbed that allows quantifications of the theoretical limits and practical scenarios in the application of causal-discovery algorithms to real-world spatiotemporal data, and applying refined causal-discovery algorithms to large, complex, and diverse climate datasets to understand physical and dynamical processes dictating interactions among atmospheric disturbances of various scales, coupling between top-of-atmosphere (TOA) radiative fluxes and surface temperature, soil moisture feedback to precipitation, and onset of the South Asian monsoon.

Specifically, utilizing synthetic data from advection-diffusion simulations, we found that the discussion of identified information flow should always be placed in the context of the physical speed of signal propagation and the ratio of the spatial to temporal resolution, cautioning the challenges involved in extracting and understanding real physics from high-dimension, large-volume data. We further applied a causal-discovery algorithm to simulation data from a dynamical system with known causality (i.e., the Lorenz system). The most significant finding is that in such a highly nonlinear system, linear causal effects can be robustly detected while the extraction of nonlinear causal effects depends crucially on whether the signs of sampled data change. This discovery reveals some practical limitations of data-driven causal discovery through partial-correlation-based independence test and offers guidelines on the pre-processing of real-world data before conducting causal inferences. With the establishment of the testbed and insights gained from the application to the Lorenz system, we constructed graphs of information flow 1) among atmospheric disturbances of various scales, where the findings show consistency with earlier results based upon dynamical analysis and meanwhile reveal for the first time the actively interacting structures of the synoptic- and planetary-scale disturbances in boreal winter; 2) among TOA radiative imbalance and surface temperature, where we found that the communications between the two fields on sub-monthly-scales mainly occur over land (monsoon regions in particular) and over polar regions, offering new insights on the spatial structure of the building blocks of climate feedbacks; 3) among atmospheric and oceanic fields (e.g., sea surface temperature, atmospheric humidity, temperature and wind) for periods prior to the onset of the South Asian monsoon, where the identified information flow reveals the significant impacts of lower-tropospheric humidity around the Maritime Continent and the northerly winds from interior Asian continent north of the Bay of Bengal on the pre-monsoon precipitation in this region; and 4) among soil moisture and precipitation in US, where the feedback of soil moisture is found to vary across climate zones (e.g., from dry to semi-dry to semi-wet and wet) and a new feedback index defined from the causal inference results offers a new metric for efficiently identifying potential biases in Earth System Model (ESM)?s representations of land-atmosphere interactions.        

In addition to the research findings discussed above, this NSF-supported project provides causal discovery algorithms that scale up to the requirements of demanding applications in climate science, fully develops the concept of ?graphs of information flow? to provide a new general tool in climate science to better understand coupled dynamical processes of the Earth?s climate system. The project is also truly inter-disciplinary, taking advantage of the latest development in the theory and implementation of causal discovery, increasingly large and complex climate datasets, and ever-growing computational resources to build pictures of the information pathways in  our climate system that are critical for studying atmospheric scale-interactions, climate feedbacks, land-atmosphere interactions and monsoon dynamics. From these pictures, new insights of the intrinsic dynamics of multiple-scale climate processes can be obtained and assessment of potential climate regime change given external forcing can be conducted. The research supported by this project has brought together expertise in climate science and computer/information science, particularly machine learning and intelligent systems to achieve a goal that also directly contributes to the NSF initiative of advancing Big Data science and engineering. This NSF project also supported the training of two PhD students and three postdoc researchers at Georgia Tech, providing them opportunities to study machine learning, climate feedbacks, monsoon dynamics, climate dynamics, and preparing them for careers in either academia, government or private sectors.
